title: isequal
summary: Test arrays for equality in size, class, and content.

gpu_support.notes: GPU tensors are gathered to the host before comparison. Future versions may add native GPU comparison paths.

description: `isequal` compares two or more arrays and returns `true` (logical 1) if they all have the same size, class, and content, and `false` (logical 0) otherwise. NaN values are NOT considered equal; use `isequaln` to treat NaN values as equal.
behaviors: `isequal(A, B)` compares two values for equality.
`isequal(A, B, C, ...)` compares all inputs against each other; returns `true` only if all are equal.
Arrays must have identical shape (size) to be equal.
Arrays must have matching data types (class) to be equal.
All corresponding elements must be identical for arrays to be equal.
NaN values are NOT equal to each other (NaN ~= NaN).
Empty arrays `[]` are equal to other empty arrays with the same shape.
Cell arrays are compared element-by-element recursively.

examples.description: Verifying that every cell starts with `[]`

faqs.question: How is `isequal` different from `==`?
faqs.answer: `isequal` returns a single logical value indicating whether all inputs are completely identical. The `==` operator performs element-wise comparison and returns an array of the same size as the inputs.

faqs.question: How does `isequal` handle NaN values?
faqs.answer: NaN values are NOT considered equal. `isequal(NaN, NaN)` returns `false`. Use `isequaln` if you want NaN values to be treated as equal.

faqs.question: Can I compare more than two arrays?
faqs.answer: Yes. `isequal(A, B, C, ...)` accepts any number of inputs and returns `true` only if all inputs are equal to each other.

faqs.question: Are empty arrays equal?
faqs.answer: Empty arrays with the same shape are equal. For example, `isequal([], [])` returns `true`, and `isequal(zeros(0,3), zeros(0,3))` returns `true`.

faqs.question: How are cell arrays compared?
faqs.answer: Cell arrays are compared element-by-element. Each corresponding pair of cells must contain equal values for the cell arrays to be equal.

faqs.question: What happens with different data types?
faqs.answer: Values of different classes are generally not equal. However, compatible numeric types (like `double` and `single`, or `double` and `logical`) may be compared after appropriate promotion.

gpu_residency: None. `isequal` gathers GPU tensors to the host for comparison. The result is always a host logical scalar.
gpu_behavior: When comparing gpuArray inputs, `isequal` gathers all tensors to the host before performing the comparison. The result is a scalar logical value on the host.
